choiceone: Fowler flaps , upper and lower rudder.
choicetwo: weight in the nose of the control surface , horn balance.
choicethree: upper and lower rudder , seal between wing’s trailing edge and leading edge of a control surface.

question: Excessive static lateral stability is an undesirable characteristic for a transport aeroplane because ;
answer: it would impose excessive demands on roll control during a sideslip.
choiceone: it would result in a proportional decline in static directional stability.
choicetwo: it would result in excessive wing loading during a co-ordinated turn.
choicethree: performing co-ordinated turns would be very difficult.

question: Excluding constants , the coefficient of induced drag ( CDi ) is the ratio of ;

question: Extension of FOWLER type trailing edge lift augmentation devices , will produce ;

choicetwo: a force which reduces drag.

question: Extension of leading edge flaps will ;

question: Flap extension at constant IAS whilst maintaining straight and level flight will increase the ;

answer: maximum lift coefficient ( CLmax ) and the drag.

question: Flaperons are controls which combine the function of ;

question: Floating due to ground effect during an approach to land will occur ;

question: “Flutter” may be caused by a ;
answer: distortion by bending and torsion of the structure causing increasing vibration in the resonance frequency.

choicetwo: high airspeed aerodynamic wing stall.
choicethree: low airspeed aerodynamic wing stall.

question: “Flutter” may be caused by a ;

choiceone: high airspeed aerodynamic wing stall.
choicetwo: combination of fuselage bending and wing torsion.
choicethree: combination roll control reversal and low speed stall.

question: Flutter of control surfaces is ;
answer:
a divergent oscillatory motion of a control surface caused by the interaction of aerodynamic forces , inertia
 forces and the stiffness of the structure.
choiceone: aileron reversal.
choicetwo: the accelerated stall of a wing.
choicethree:
divergent oscillatory motion of a control surface caused by the interaction of aerodynamic , inertia and
 friction forces.

question: Flutter sensitivity of an aeroplane wing is reduced by ;

choiceone: statically unstable - dynamically neutral.
choicetwo: statically stable - dynamically unstable.
choicethree: statically unstable - dynamically stable.

question: How can a pilot recognise static stick force stability in an aeroplane during flight ?

choicetwo: The elevator stick force remains constant with speed changes.

answer: To maintain a speed below the trim speed requires a pull force.

choicetwo: When speed increases the pull force increases.

question: Ignoring downwash effects on the tailplane , extension of Fowler flaps , will produce ;

choiceone: no pitching moment.
choicetwo: a nose-up pitching moment.
choicethree: a force which reduces drag.

question:
In a convergent tube with an incompressible sub-sonic airflow , the following pressure changes will occur ;
 Ps = static pressure.
 Pdyn = dynamic pressure.
 Ptot = total pressure.
answer: Ps decreases , Pdyn increases , Ptot remains constant.
choiceone: Ps decreases , Pdyn increases , static temperature increases.
choicetwo: Ps decreases , Ptot increases , static temperature decreases.
choicethree: Ps increases , Pdyn decreases , Ptot remains constant.

question: In a co-ordinated horizontal turn , the magnitude of the centripetal force at 45 degrees of bank ;
answer: is equal to the weight of the aeroplane.
choiceone: is equal to the lift of the aeroplane.
choicetwo: is greater than the lift of the aeroplane.
choicethree: has a vertical component.

question:
In a skidding turn ( the nose pointing inwards ) , compared with a co-ordinated turn , the bank angle (i) and the “ball” or slip
indicator (ii) are respectively ;
answer: (i) too small , (ii) displaced towards the high wing.
choiceone: (i) too large , (ii) displaced towards the high wing.
choicetwo: (i) too small , (ii) displaced towards the low wing.
choicethree: (i) too large , (ii) displaced towards the low wing.

question:
In a slipping turn ( nose pointing outwards ) , compared to a co-ordinated turn , the bank angle (i) and the “ball” or slip
indicator (ii) are respectively ;
answer: (i) too large , (ii) displaced towards the low wing.
choiceone: (i) too large , (ii) displaced towards the high wing.
choicetwo: (i) too small , (ii) displaced towards the low wing.
choicethree: (i) too small , (ii) displaced towards the high wing.

question:
In a stationary subsonic streamline flow pattern , if the streamlines converge , in this part of the pattern , the static pressure
(I) will .......... and the velocity (II) will ............ ;
answer: (I) decrease , (II) increase.
choiceone: (I) increase , (II) decrease.
choicetwo: (I) decrease , (II) decrease.
choicethree: (I) increase , (II) increase.

question: In a steady co-ordinated horizontal turn , lift is ;
answer: greater than in straight and level flight , because it must balance the weight and generate the centripetal force.
choiceone: greater than in straight and level flight , because it must generate the centrifugal force.
choicetwo: greater than in straight and level flight because it must balance the centripetal force.
choicethree: equal to the aeplane weight.

question: In a steady , horizontal , co-ordinated turn ;
answer: thrust equals drag , because there is equilibrium of forces along the direction of flight.
choiceone: thrust equals drag , because drag is the same as in straight and level flight.
choicetwo: thrust is greater than drag , because the centrifugal force reduces the aeroplane speed.
choicethree: thrust is greater than drag , because the excess thrust also supplies the centripetal force.

question: In a steady level , co-ordinated turn , the load factor n and the stalling speed VS will be ;
answer: n greater than 1 , VS higher than in straight and level flight.
choiceone: n greater than 1 , VS lower than in straight and level flight.
choicetwo: n smaller than 1 , VS lower than in straight and level flight.
choicethree: n smaller than 1 , VS higher than in straight and level flight.

question: In a steady straight climb at climb angle “gamma” , the lift of an aeroplane with weight W is approximately ;
answer: W * cos ( gamma )
choiceone: W * ( 1-sin ( gamma ) )
choicetwo: W * ( 1-tan ( gamma ) )
choicethree: W / cos ( gamma )

question: In a straight , steady climb the thrust must be ;
answer: greater than the drag because it must also balance a component of weight.
choiceone: greater than drag because more lift has to be produced.
choicetwo: lower than the drag because it is assisted by a component of weight.
choicethree: equal to the drag.

question: In a straight steady descent , which of the following statements is correct ?
answer: Lift is less than weight , load factor is less than 1.
choiceone: Lift is equal to weight , load factor is equal to 1.
choicetwo: Lift is equal to weight , load factor is less than 1.
choicethree: Lift is less than weight , load factor is equal to 1.

question:
In a twin engine jet aeroplane ( engines mounted below the low wings ) the thrust is suddenly increased. Which elevator
deflection will be required to maintain the pitching moment zero ?
answer: Down.
choiceone: Up.
choicetwo: No elevator movement will required because the thrust line of the engines remains unchanged.
choicethree: It depends on the position of the centre of gravity.

question:
In case of supersonic flow retarded by a normal shock wave a high efficiency ( low loss in total pressure ) can be obtained if
the Mach number in front of the shock is ;
answer: small but still supersonic.
choiceone: lower than 1.
choicetwo: exactly 1.
choicethree: high ( supersonic ).

question: In case the Mach trimmer fails ;
answer: the Mach number must be limited.
choiceone: try to relocate the centre-of-gravity aft.
choicetwo: the speed must be kept constant.
choicethree: the aeroplane weight must be limited.

question: In comparison to a conventional aerofoil section , typical shape characteristics of a supercritical aerofoil section are ;
answer: a larger nose radius , flatter upper surface and negative as well as positive camber.
choiceone: a larger nose radius , flatter lower surface and negative as well as positive camber.
choicetwo: a sharper pointed nose , negative camber and a flatter upper surface.
choicethree: a sharper pointed nose , flatter lower surface and positive camber at the rear of the aerofoil section.

question: In general , control forces are reduced by ;
answer: a horn balance , servo tab and spring tab.
choiceone: mass balancing , a trim tab and spring tab.
choicetwo: a balance tab , forward shift of the CG and a servo tab.
choicethree: a servo tab , spring tab and mass balancing.

question:
In general , directional controllability with one engine inoperative on a multi-engine aeroplane is adversely affected by: ;
 1. high temperature.
 2. low temperature.
 3. aft CG location.
 4. forward CG location.
 5. high altitude.
 6. low altitude
 The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is ;

In general , directional controllability with one engine inoperative on a multi-engine aeroplane is favourably affected by ;
 1. high temperature.
 2. low temperature.
 3. aft CG location.
 4. forward CG location.
 5. high altitude.
 6. low altitude.
 The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is ;

In general transport aeroplanes with power assisted flight controls are fitted with an adjustable stabilizer instead of trim tabs
on the elevator. This is because ;
answer: effectiveness of trim tabs is insufficient for those aeroplanes
choiceone: trim tab deflection increases Mcrit
choicetwo: mechanical adjustment of trim tabs creates too many problems
choicethree: the pilot does not feel the stick forces at all

question: In order to fly a rate one turn at a higher airspeed , the bank angle must be ;
answer: increased and the turn radius will increase.
choiceone: decreased and the turn radius will decrease.
choicetwo: decreased and the turn radius will increase
choicethree: increased and the turn radius will decrease.

question:
In order to maintain constant speed during a level , co-ordinated turn , compared with straight and level flight , the pilot
must ;
answer: increase thrust/power and angle of attack.
choiceone: increase thrust/power and decrease angle of attack.
choicetwo: increase thrust/power and keep angle of attack unchanged.
choicethree: increase angle of attack and keep thrust/power unchanged.

question:
In order to maintain straight and level flight at a constant airspeed , whilst the flaps are being retracted , the angle of attack
must be ;
answer: increased
choiceone: increased or decreased depending upon the type of flap
choicetwo: held constant
choicethree: decreased

question: In order to perform a steady level turn at constant speed in an aeroplane , the pilot must ;
answer: increase thrust/power and angle of attack.
choiceone: increase thrust/power and decrease angle of attack.
choicetwo: increase angle of attack and keep thrust/power unchanged.
choicethree: increase thrust/power and keep angle of attack unchanged.

question:
In order to provide an adequate “buffet boundary” at the commencement of the cruise a speed of 1.3 VS is used. At a mass of
120.000 kg this is a CAS of 180 knots. If the mass of the aeroplane is increased to 135.000 kg the value of 1.3 VS will be ;
answer: increased to 191 knots , drag will increase and air distance per kg of fuel will decrease.
choiceone: increased to 202 knots but , since the same angle of attack is used , drag and range will remain the same.
choicetwo: increased to 191 knots , drag will decrease and air distance per kg of fuel will increase.
choicethree: unaffected as VS always occurs at the same angle of attack.

question: In straight and level flight , as speed is increased ;
answer: the elevator is deflected further downwards and the trim tab further upwards.
choiceone: the elevator and trim tab do not move.
choicetwo: the elevator is deflected further upwards and the trim tab further downwards.
choicethree: both elevator and trim tab are deflected further downwards.

question: In straight and level flight , as speed is reduced ;
answer: the elevator is deflected further upwards and the trim tab further downwards.
choiceone: the elevator and trim tab do not move.
choicetwo: both elevator and trim tab are deflected further upwards.
choicethree: the elevator is deflected further downwards and the trim tab further upwards.

question:
In straight and level flight at a speed of 1.3 VS , the lift coefficient , expressed as a percentage of its maximum ( CLmax ) ,
would be ;
In straight flight , as speed is increased , whilst trimming to keep the stick force zero ;
answer: the elevator is deflected further downwards and the trim tab further upwards.
choiceone: both elevator and trim tab are deflected further downwards.
choicetwo: the elevator and trim tab do not move.
choicethree: the elevator is deflected further upwards and the trim tab further downwards.

question: In straight flight , as speed is reduced , whilst trimming to keep the stick force zero ;
answer: the elevator is deflected further upwards and the trim tab further downwards.
choiceone: the elevator and trim tab do not move.
choicetwo: both elevator and trim tab are deflected further upwards.
choicethree: the elevator is deflected further downwards and the trim tab further upwards.

question: In supersonic flight aerofoil pressure distribution is ;
answer: rectangular.
choiceone: triangular.
choicetwo: the same as in subsonic flight.
choicethree: irregular.

question: In supersonic flight , all disturbances produced by an aeroplane are ;
answer: in between a conical area , depending on the Mach Number.
choiceone: very weak and negligible.
choicetwo: outside the conical area depending on the Mach Number.
choicethree: in front of the aeroplane.

question: In supersonic flight , all disturbances produced by an aeroplane are ;
answer: within a conical zone , dependent on the Mach Number.
choiceone: outside the conical area depending on the Mach Number.
choicetwo: in front of the aeroplane.
choicethree: very weak and negligible.

question: In the event of failure of the Mach trimmer ;
answer: the Mach number must be limited.
choiceone: the speed must be kept constant.
choicetwo: the centre of gravity must be moved aft.
choicethree: the aeroplane mass must be limited.

question: In the transonic range lift will decrease at the shock stall due to the ;
answer: separation of the boundary layer at the shock waves.
choiceone: attachment of the shock wave on the trailing edge of the wing.
choicetwo: appearance of the bow wave.
choicethree: first appearance of a shock wave at the upper side of the wing.

question: In the transonic range the aeroplane characteristics are strongly determined by the ;
answer: Mach Number.
choiceone: TAS.
choicetwo: IAS.
choicethree: CAS.

question: In transonic flight the ailerons will be less effective than in subsonic flight because ;
answer: aileron deflection only partly affects the pressure distribution around the wing.
choiceone: behind the shock wave pressure is lower.
choicetwo: aileron down deflection moves the shock wave forward.
choicethree: aileron deflection only affects the air in front of the shock wave.

question: In twin engine aeroplanes with propellers turning clockwise as seen from behind ;
answer: the left engine is the critical engine.
choiceone: the “minimum control speed” is determined by the failure of the right engine.
choicetwo: the right engine is the critical engine.
choicethree: the left engine produces a higher yaw moment if the right engine fails than vice versa.

question: In twin-engine aeroplanes with right turning propellers ;
answer: the left engine is the critical motor.
choiceone: the left engine produces a higher yaw moment if the right engine fails than vice versa.
choicetwo: the “minimum control speed” is determined by the failure of the right engine.
choicethree: the right engine is the critical motor.

question: In what flight phase are the outboard ailerons ( if present ) not operated ?
answer: During cruise flight.
choiceone: During take-off , until lift-off.
choicetwo: In the approach phase , before landing.
choicethree: During a landing with strong and gusty crosswind to avoid overcontrolling the aeroplane.

question: In what phase of flight are the outboard ailerons ( if fitted ) not active ?
answer: Cruise.
choiceone: Take-off , until lift-off.
choicetwo: Approach.
choicethree: Landing with a strong and gusty crosswind , to avoid over-controlling the aeroplane.

question: In what way do (1) induced drag and (2) parasite drag alter with increasing speed in straight and level flight ?
answer: (1) decreases and (2) increases.
choiceone: (1) increases and (2) decreases.
choicetwo: (1) decreases and (2) decreases.
choicethree: (1) increases and (2) increases.

question: In what way is the longitudinal stability affected by the degree of positive camber of the aerofoil ?
answer:
No effect , because camber of the aerofoil produces a constant pitch down moment coefficient , independent
 of angle of attack.
choiceone: Positive , because the centre of pressure shifts rearward at increasing angle of attack.
choicetwo: Negative , because the lift vector rotates forward at increasing angle of attack.
choicethree: Positive , because the lift vector rotates backward at increasing angle of attack.

question: In which phase of the take-off is the aerodynamic effect of ice located on the wing leading edge most critical ?
answer: The last part of the rotation.
choiceone: The take-off run.
choicetwo: All phases of the take-off are equally critical.
choicethree: During climb with all engines operating.

question: In which situation would the wing lift of an aeroplane in straight and level flight have the highest value ?
answer: Forward centre of gravity and idle thrust.
choiceone: Aft centre of gravity and take-off thrust.
choicetwo: Aft centre of gravity and idle thrust.
choicethree: Forward centre of gravity and take-off thrust.

question: Increase of the delta load factor due to a given vertical upgust at a given EAS occurs when ;
answer: the slope of the CL-alpha graph becomes steeper.
choiceone: the wing loading increases.
choicetwo: the weight increases.
choicethree: the altitude increases.

question: Increase of wing loading will ;
answer: increase the stall speeds.
choiceone: decrease take off speeds.
choicetwo: decrease the minimum gliding angle.
choicethree: increase CLmax.

question:
Increasing air density will have the following effect on the drag of a body in an airstream ; ( angle of attack and TAS are
constant )
answer: the drag increases.
choiceone: this has no effect.
choicetwo: the drag is only affected by the ground speed.
choicethree: the drag decreases.

question:
Increasing dynamic pressure will have the following effect on the drag of an aeroplane ; ( all other factors of importance
remaining constant )
answer: at speeds greater than the minimum drag speed , drag increases.
choiceone: drag increases across the whole speed range.
choicetwo: none.
choicethree: drag decreases across the whole speed range.

question: Increasing dynamic pressure will have the following effect on the total drag of an aeroplane ;
answer: at speeds above the minimum drag speed , total drag increases.
choiceone: total drag decreases across the whole speed range.
choicetwo: at speeds below the minimum drag speed , total drag decreases.
choicethree: total drag increases across the whole speed range.

question: Increasing the aspect ratio of a wing ;
answer: decreases induced drag.
choiceone: increases induced drag.
choicetwo: decreases gust load.
choicethree: increases stall speed.

question: Increasing the number of propeller blades will ;
answer: increase the maximum absorption of power.
choiceone: decrease the torque in the propeller shaft at maximum power.
choicetwo: increase the noise level at maximum power.
choicethree: increase the propeller efficiency.

question: Induced drag at constant IAS is affected by ;
answer: aeroplane weight.
choiceone: aeroplane wing location.
choicetwo: engine thrust.
choicethree: angle between wing chord and fuselage centre line.

question: Induced drag is created by the ;
answer: spanwise flow pattern resulting in the tip vortices.
choiceone: interference of the air stream between wing and fuselage.
choicetwo: separation of the boundary layer over the wing.
choicethree: propeller wash blowing across the wing.

question: Induced drag is the result of ;
answer: downwash generated by tip vortices.
choiceone: propeller slipstream over the wing.
choicetwo: aerodynamic interaction between aeroplane parts.
choicethree: boundary layer separation on the aft portion of the wing.

question: Induced drag may be reduced by ;
answer: an increase in aspect ratio.
choiceone: an increase in the taper ratio of the wing.
choicetwo: the use of a wing tip with a much thinner aerofoil.
choicethree: a decrease of the aspect ratio.

question: Interference drag is the result of ;
answer: aerodynamic interaction between aeroplane parts ( e.g. wing/fuselage ).
choiceone: separation of the induced vortex.
choicetwo: downwash behind the wing.

question: Is a transport aeroplane allowed to fly at a higher Mach number than the “buffet-onset” Mach number in 1 g flight ?
answer: No , this is not acceptable.
choiceone: Yes , if you want to fly fast at very high altitudes.
choicetwo: Yes , but only during approach.
choicethree: Yes , this causes no problems.

question: Just above the critical Mach number the first evidence of a shock wave will appear at the ;
answer: upper side of the wing.
choiceone: trailing edge of the wing.
choicetwo: lower side of the wing.
choicethree: leading edge of the wing.

question: Lift is generated when ;
answer: the flow direction of a certain mass of air is changed.
choiceone: a certain mass of air is retarded.
choicetwo: a symmetrical aerofoil is placed in a high velocity air stream at zero angle of attack.
choicethree: a certain mass of air is accelerated in its flow direction.

question: Lift is the ;
answer: component of the total aerodynamic force , perpendicular to the local flow.
choiceone: component of the total aerodynamic force , perpendicular to the undisturbed airflow.
choicetwo: component of the total aerodynamic force , perpendicular to the mean aerodynamic chord.
choicethree: vertical component of the total aerodynamic force , perpendicular to the undisturbed airflow.

question: Load factor is ;
answer: Lift / Weight
choiceone: 1 / Bank angle
choicetwo: Wing loading
choicethree: Weight / Lift

question: Load factor is increased by ;
answer: upward gusts.
choiceone: an increase in aeroplane mass.
choicetwo: a decrease in air density.
choicethree: forward CG movement.

question: Longitudinal stability is directly influenced by ;
answer: centre of gravity position.
choiceone: the vertical stabiliser.
choicetwo: wing dihedral.
choicethree: elevator deflection only.

question: Longitudinal static stability is created by the fact that the ;

choiceone: centre of gravity is located in front of the leading edge of the wing.
choicetwo: aeroplane possesses a large trim speed range.

question: Low speed pitch-up can be caused by a significant thrust ;

choiceone: increase with engines located on the rear fuselage.
choicetwo: decrease with podded engines located beneath a low-mounted wing.
choicethree: decrease with engines located on the rear fuselage.

question: Low speed pitch up is caused by the ;

choicetwo: wing tip vortex.
choicethree: spanwise flow on a swept forward wing.

question: Low speed pitch up is caused by the ;

question: Mach buffet occurs ;

question: Mass-balancing of control surfaces is used to ;

question: Mcrit is increased by ;

choiceone: sweepback , dihedral and thin aerofoils.

question: Mcrit is the free stream Mach Number at which ;

choiceone: shockstall occurs.
choicetwo: the critical angle of attack is reached.
choicethree: Mach buffet occurs.

question: Minimum drag of an aeroplane in straight and level flight occurs at the ;
answer: maximum CL-CD ratio.

question: Negative tail stall is ;

question:
On a jet aeroplane ( engines mounted below the low wing ) the thrust is suddenly increased. Which of these statements is

answer: The elevator must be deflected downward.
choiceone: The amount of elevator deflection is independent of CG location.
choicetwo: No elevator deflection be will required because the thrust line of the engines remains unchanged.

question: On a large transport aeroplane , the auto-slat system ;

question: On a swept wing aeroplane at low airspeed , the “pitch up” phenomenon ;

question:
On an asymmetrical , single curve aerofoil , in subsonic airflow , at low angle of attack , when the angle of attack is

question: One advantage of a movable-stabilizer system compared with an elevator trim system is that ;

choicetwo: the complete system ( structure and control mechanism ) weighs less.

question: One disadvantage of wing sweep is the stalling characteristics. At the stall ;

choicethree: tip stall will occur first , which produces a nose-down moment

question: One disadvantage of wing sweepback is ;

question: One important advantage the turbulent boundary layer has over the laminar layer is that ;

question: One method to compensate adverse yaw is ;

question: One of the requirements for positive dynamic stability is:

question: Outboard ailerons ( if present ) are normally used ;

question: Positive static lateral stability is the tendency of an aeroplane to ;

choiceone:
roll to the left in the case of a sideslip angle ( with the aeroplane nose pointing to the right of the incoming
 flow ).
choicetwo: roll to the left in a right turn.
choicethree: roll to the right in a right turn.

question: Positive static lateral stability is the tendency of an aeroplane to ;
answer: roll to the left in the case of a positive sideslip angle ( aeroplane nose to the left ).

question: Positive static longitudinal stability means that a ;
answer: nose-down moment occurs after encountering an up-gust.
choiceone: nose-up moment occurs with a speed change at constant angle of attack.
choicetwo: nose-up moment occurs after encountering an up-gust.
choicethree: nose-down moment occurs with a speed change at constant angle of attack.

question: Positive static stability of an aeroplane means that following a disturbance from the equilibrium condition ;

question: Propeller blade twist is the ;

question: Propeller efficiency is ;

question: Which of the following increases the maximum duration of a glide ?

question: Which of the following lists contain aeroplane design features that all increase static lateral stability ?

question: Which of the following parameters can be read from the parabolic polar diagram of an aeroplane ?

question: Which of the following provides a positive contribution to static directional stability ?

question: Which of the following situations leads to a decreasing stall speed ( IAS ) ?

question: Which of the following statements about a constant speed propeller is correct ?

choicethree: The RPM decreases with increasing aeroplane speed.

question: Which of the following statements about a Mach trimmer is correct ?
answer:
A Mach trimmer corrects the change in stick force stability of a swept wing aeroplane above a certain Mach
 number.
choiceone: A straight wing aeroplane always needs a Mach trimmer for flying at Mach numbers close to MMO.
choicetwo: A Mach trimmer reduces the stick force stability of a straight wing aeroplane to zero at high Mach numbers.
choicethree: The Mach trimmer corrects the natural tendency of a swept wing aeroplane to pitch-up.

question:

question: Which of the following statements about dihedral is correct ?

question: Which of the following statements about stall speed is correct ?

question: Which of the following statements about static lateral and directional stability is correct ?
answer:
An aeroplane with an excessive static directional stability in relation to its static lateral stability , will be

The effects of static lateral and static directional stability are completely independent of each other because

choicetwo: Static directional stability can be increased by installing more powerful engines.
choicethree:
An aeroplane with an excessive static directional stability in relation to its static lateral stability , will be
 prone to “Dutch roll”.

question: Which of the following statements is true ?
